items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Levels have risen again on the Upper River Derwent and Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water in response to overnight rainfall associated with Storm Pia. Levels have peaked this morning and are forecast to start receding again throughout Thursday 21st and into Friday 22nd December before more persistent, potentially heavy rain is forecast to move through on the 23rd and 24th of December which is likely to see levels rise again.

Flooding is affecting locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the shores of Derwent Water.

We will continue to monitor the forecasts and re-issue this alert and associated warnings if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Churn following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. River levels are expected to continue gradually falling over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Cherwell following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thrupp area. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. Levels are currently falling, but are expected to rise over the next couple of days in response to recent rainfall, especially in the Thrupp area.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels are now falling slowly but remain high at Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may still be affected include Llanymynech.

Peaks: Llanymynech peaked at 3.38m on Tuesday, 19/12/23; Cae Howel peaked at 3.81m on Wednesday, 20/12/2023.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am, 22/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high around Malton and Low Marishes due to recent persistent rainfall, but continue to fall slowly. Areas most at risk include low lying land around Low Marishes and Yedingham. River levels in Malton are continuing to fall below levels of concern. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Friday 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the River Glyme following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Woodstock area. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. River levels have fallen following previous rain on the River Evenlode, but levels remain high on the River Glyme near Woodstock. River levels are expected to gradually fall on the River Glyme over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still high but are beginning to fall on the River Thames. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Abingdon area. Today and overnight is forecast to be mainly dry. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Wolvercote and New Botley areas. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. We expect river levels to continue slowly rising over the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the Lower Dorset Frome. Levels at our East Stoke Gauge are remaining high and our Stinsford gauge levels are falling slowly, but this alert is likely to remain in force for at least the next 2 days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for very little rain this evening and over the week.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high and steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am, 22/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Avon and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Middle Hampshire Avon and its Tributaries due to rainfall in the last 48 hours and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 21st December 2023, until the weekend.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads during the current neap tides and high surge levels. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few days. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, the River Hull and Roam Drain due to recent prolonged rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area including low lying land around Hempholme. Levels are expected to stay high for several days. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00am on Friday 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the Lower River Derwent at Thornton Lock and Elvington due to recent persistent rainfall. We expect levels to remain high for the next few days but to continue falling slowly. Levels at Buttercrambe and Stamford Bridge have continued to fall and are below levels of concern, but floodwater is likely to remain on low lying land for a number of days. We are monitoring levels closely and have staff checking flood defences in the area. Continue acting on your flood plan. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Friday 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are remaining high in the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Levels are forecast to remain above the Flood Alert level.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for very little rain this evening and over the week.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. River levels are expected to continue gradually falling over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks.
The groundwater level at Draycot Foliat is higher than normal for this time of year but groundwater levels are currently declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 23/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels remain high, but are slowly falling on the Chertsey Bourne following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Chertsey area. It is forecast to be mainly dry this evening, 21/12/23, with some light rain overnight. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are falling on the Bristol Avon and Semington Brook. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

Small amounts of rain are forecast over the next few days but river levels are expected to keep falling.

We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and river levels closely.

This message will be updated by the morning of Friday 22nd December, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.01m and stable. This level is being maintained by water being pumped off the moor.
The pumping station drain level is 8.05m and falling steadily in response to pumping activities. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is expected when this level exceeds 8.35m. 
Blustery conditions and occasional showers sometimes with strong winds are forecast for the rest of the week.
We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi pumping stations and will continue to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. Please remain mindful of local water levels and do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water.
Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.
This message will be updated by 1pm on Friday 22/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: Strong winds combined with a tidal surge may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast between 0:00am and 02:00am tomorrow morning, Friday 22 December.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 3.44 mAODN at 1:00 am, on Friday 22 December, which is 0.73m above tide tables, wind Force 6, westerly. (m AODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Friday at 15:00 pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 22 December.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 21st December 2023. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Gt Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads during the current neap tides and high surge levels. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few days. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 2am and 4am tomorrow, Friday 22nd December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.17 mAODN at 3am, on Friday 22nd December, wind Force 7, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The current series of high tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 22nd December.

items.message: This flood alert has now been removed as coastal conditions have improved. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides in this area. items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 21st December 2023, until the weekend. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads during the current neap tides and high surge levels. It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few days. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of a higher than usual tide associated with Storm Pia.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.98mAOD at 21:15 on 21/12/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 178 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 08:00 on 22/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This alert has now been removed as coastal conditions have eased. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely between 2am and 4am tomorrow, Friday 22nd December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions. Areas most at risk are around Southwold Harbour, Ferry Road, the bottom of Queens Road and Constitution Hill, North Road, the bottom of Pier Avenue, and Mights Road in Southwold, and Bridge Road and Hillside Road in Reydon. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.17 mAODN, at 3am on Friday 22nd December, wind Force 7, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). High water at Southwold will be around one hour later. The current series of high tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 22nd December.

items.description: The A12 at Blythburgh
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely between 2am and 4am tomorrow, Friday 22nd December. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions. The location most at risk of flooding is the A12 at Blythburgh. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.17mAODN at 3am on Friday 22nd December, wind Force 7, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). High water at Blythburgh will be around one hour later. The current series of high tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 22nd December.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide and large surge forecast at 07:15 PM on 21/12/2023.
Areas most at risk include low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths. No property flooding is expected.
We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow's high tides, however we will continue to monitor levels closely.
We will update or remove this message by 10:00 AM on 22/12/2023.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: This flood alert has now been removed as coastal conditions have improved. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides in this area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This flood alert has now been removed as coastal conditions have improved. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides in this area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Bawdsey Quay and Felixstowe Ferry
items.message: This warning has now been removed as coastal conditions have improved. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides in this area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This flood alert has now been removed as coastal conditions have improved. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides in this area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise. Since Tuesday 12/12/2023, just 12mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End. The groundwater level at Whitedale Farm has risen by 3.11m during that time. Ongoing cellar flooding will be affecting a significant number of properties on West Street and East Street. Groundwater will be affecting the sewerage system, and Fareham Road is currently flooded. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to peak by the end of the week. More properties are expected to be impacted by cellar flooding in this time. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and continue to monitor the situation. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise slowly. In the last week, just 13mm of rain has been recorded at Walderton, and the groundwater level at Finchdean has risen by 18cm. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are flowing. Pumps which prevent water from entering property may be required for properties in all villages. It is possible that road flooding will be ongoing throughout the area. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). The groundwater level is expected to peak early next week. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. Please remove valuables from cellars, and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.
The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year but is currently very slowly declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries of the lower River Witham from Blankney to Sleaford

floodArea.riverOrSea: Kyme Eau, River Slea, Billinghay Skirth, Ruskington Beck, Old River Slea and Leasingham Beck

items.message: River levels are gradually falling, they do however remain high in the Blankney to Sleaford area. Rainfall from the last week will keep river levels high for the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 13:00 on 22nd December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Hull due to recent rainfall, high groundwater levels and the effect of the tides. Flooding may affect locations near the Beverley and Barmston Drain and River Hull, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including the central River Hull area around Arram, Tickton, Beverley, and Dunswell. River levels are expected to remain high for a number of days. We are in the area operating pumping stations and checking defences, as well as operating flood defences across the wider catchment area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Friday 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are expected to high, but steady at the Torksey gauge this evening, 21/12/2023, as a result of high river levels coinciding with a higher than usual tide.

Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated by 9:00 in the morning of, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated before 10:00am tomorrow 22/12/23.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 22/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
Upper River Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may remain. Isolated light showers are possible over the next few days, but they are not expected to cause river levels to rise significantly again. We will continue to monitor the rainfall forecast and river levels closely.

items.description: Riseley Brook in Bedford Borough
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels remain high after Tuesdays rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester, may also be affected. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to start falling soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10 am tomorrow, 22/12/23.

items.description: Weymouth Rivers and Streams
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Wey, Preston Brook, River Jordan due to rising groundwater levels and previous heavy rainfall.

Levels at our Broadway gauge are slowly receding.

The forecast this evening and over the remainder of the week is for very little rain.

Flooding remains possible at the River Wey to Radipole Lake, Preston Brook and River Jordan.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels on the Upper River Wey have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. It is forecast to be cloudy this morning, 21/12/23, with outbreaks of light rain, then turning brighter this afternoon. We have been clearing debris from weed screens and we will continue to monitor the forecast.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are continuing to fall after Tuesdays rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10 am tomorrow, 22/12/23.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are slowly rising on the River Windrush in following rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Newbridge area. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Mythe Bridge river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. 
Observed peaks:- Mythe 2.8m at 19:00 20/12/23, Tewkesbury 3.0m at 19:45 20/12/23, Haw Bridge 3.9m at 17:45 20/12/23.
River levels have peaked and will remain high, with no further rise forecasted. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Local Authorities.  
This message will be updated on Friday, 22/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are continuing to fall after Tuesdays rainfall.  Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are those around the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 22/12/23.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels in the Upper River Hull catchment remain high due to recent rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill. River levels are expected to remain high for several days as groundwater is yet to peak in some areas. West Beck is also particulalry high. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action, avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Friday 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 3 pm on 21/12/23. The causeway at Earith may have some standing water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 32 cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 37cm of water on the road. Norfolk County Council have closed Welney causeway. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8 am tomorrow, 22/12/23.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, and close to the surface. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water could also affect the B2141 at Chilgrove. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days (up to and including 25/12/2023). Groundwater at Chilgrove's borehole, is expected to continue falling, and water on the B2141 might reduce slightly. At the East Dean borehole, groundwater will stay at the surface. Flood impacts are expected to remain until the middle of January, and potentially longer, or affecting more people if wet weather returns. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 27/12/2023

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels are gradually falling, they do however remain high in the Heighington to Dunston area. Rainfall from the last week will keep river levels high for the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 13:00 on 22nd December 2023, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: The Rivers Deben and Lark
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for today.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have fallen back across the West of Dorset area but levels will remain high for some time. Some minor roads, especially in valley bottoms, are likely to be flooded for up to two days after rainfall. 
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick cover that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year is for limited amounts of rainfall which makes further property flooding unlikely until into the new year when a more unsettled period is expected.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Friday 22nd December.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for today.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Middle River Roding
items.message:
River levels are now falling following heavy rainfall on Tuesday 19th December. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

There is no more heavy rainfall forecast over the next 3 days and we do not expect river levels to rise again. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations.

Our incident response staff are constantly monitoring the situation and are ready to respond if required. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely to remain until tomorrow, Friday 22nd December. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message tomorrow morning, Friday 22nd December.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. Further light rainfall is forecast over the coming days, but we do not expect this to have a significant impact on river levels. 
We continue to monitor the situation and the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Steventon area. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the next couple of days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
This flood alert remains in force due to strong winds at high tide. The first forecast high water is at 13:30 on 21/12/23 with a level of 4.16m AOD and a Force 7 westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high-water time at Hinkley. The second forecast high water is at 02:15 am on 22/12/23 with a level of 3.92m AOD and a Force 7 westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Hinkley. m AOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables.

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time and conditions may apply for a period either side of the high tide. Flooding is possible for the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.
High winds are exacerbating conditions on the coast. These winds are forecast to ease in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. We are monitoring the situation, and this message will be updated by 10:00 am on Friday 22/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, but currently slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will continue, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days (up to and including 25/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue to slowly fall through to next week, and possibly through to the New Year. Groundwater flood impacts might reduce by a small amount by January. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 27/12/2023

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are currently high but starting to stabilise on the lower River Kennet following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, especially in the Theale area. Further outbreaks of light rain are forecast for Thursday morning and afternoon, this should clear overnight. Further rain is expected early Friday morning which should clear through the day. River levels are expected to stabilise and start to gradually fall over the next few days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for today.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Patcham
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, but slowly falling at the Ladies Mile borehole. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days (up to and including 25/12/2023). Groundwater should continue to slowly fall this week, without flood impacts occurring. Longer term weather forecasting is very difficult. Between Christmas and January unsettled weather is forecast, but with the wettest areas possibly in the west of England. From mid January there is a suggestion of a colder and drier spell. If intense or persistent rain avoids the area, groundwater could fall through to February 2024. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. Further groundwater rises are still possible. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will re issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Rainfall over the last week is causing River levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 14:00 on 22nd December 2023, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have fallen back across Cranborne Chase, but levels will remain high for some time. Some minor roads, especially in valley bottoms, are likely to be flooded for up to two days after rainfall. 
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick cover that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year is for limited amounts of rainfall which makes further property flooding unlikely until into the new year when a more unsettled period is expected.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Friday 22nd December.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high at the Salisbury Bourne river gauge on the River Bourne due to the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. Levels at our Ebbesbourne Wake and Salisbury gauges are receding but remain high.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for very little rain this evening and over the week.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 22/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover are high, and continuing to rise in response to the rainfall received over the last month. We expect groundwater to be affecting cellars in Appleshaw, the sewer network in Penton Mewsey, and the main road at Penton Grafton. In the next 3 days, cellar flooding is also expected in Hatherden. Tomorrow (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 20mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Friday (22/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. We expect the spring at Biddesden to flow from Friday (22/12/2023). Cellar flooding in Penton Grafton and groundwater emergence into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton is possible by the end of the week. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove valuables from cellars and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and have risen 92cm in the last week. We expect cellar flooding in the south end of the village to be occurring imminently. From Wednesday 20/12/2023, cellar flooding could occur at the Dolphin Inn pub, and impacts to the sewerage network could be experienced. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. We expect that more cellars in Hursley will begin to experience flooding impacts during that time. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River flows are high and are slowly falling. However, high tides are expected to raise river levels later tonight, as a result of Storm Pia. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 22:15 on 21/12/23, and is forecast to reach approximately 5.13m. The following high tide is expected at 10:30 on 22/12/23, and is forecast to reach approximately 4.43m. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land on Trowlock Island. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area checking defences and operating weirs to reduce flood risk. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high but slowly falling following a week of mostly dry weather. The winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for several weeks and there is a small amount of water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling during that time. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Cellar flooding caused by groundwater remains a possibility this winter. Please remain prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please check that they can operate effectively. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River flows are high and are slowly falling. However, high tides are expected to raise river levels later tonight, as a result of Storm Pia. The next high tide is expected at Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington at 22:30 on 21/12/23, and is forecast to reach approximately 5.15m. The following high tide is expected at 10:45 on 22/12/23, and is forecast to reach approximately 4.45m. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area checking defences and operating weirs to reduce flood risk. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have fallen back in the West Wiltshire Downs and the Vale of Wardour, but some boreholes are showing a continuing, but gentle rise further east, especially in the River Bourne catchment. By the weekend, all levels are expected to be falling slightly.
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick covers that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year is for limited amounts of rainfall which makes further property flooding unlikely until into the new year when a more unsettled period is expected.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Friday 22nd December.

items.description: North West Norfolk Rivers
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: In Twyford and Hensting, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (365mm) was recorded at Otterbourne. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at our borehole in West Meon Hut has risen by 17cm. In the next 4 days, cellar flooding will begin to affect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Minor impact flooding to Hensting Lane could occur from early next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: In the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (298mm) has been recorded in Andover. At Vernham Dean, the current rate of rise is 34cm per day. In the next 5 days, groundwater flooding will affect a small number of cellars in Upton. Septic tanks will also struggle to operate properly. We do not expect significant impacts to property at Vernham Dean, Hurstbourne Tarrant, Stoke or St Marybourne until later this winter. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. We will continue to monitor the forecast. In Upton, please remove any valuables from cellars and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. We advise all residents in the Bourne Valley to remain prepared for potential impacts over the next few weeks. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: In Bramdean and Cheriton, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (364mm) was recorded at Bishops Sutton. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at our borehole in West Meon Hut has increased by 17cm. In the next 4 days, cellar flooding will begin to affect a small number of cellars in Cheriton. It is unlikely that cellar flooding will affect property in Bramdean for another few weeks. Today (Tuesday 19/12/2023), up to 13mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. Dry weather is expected from Wednesday (20/12/2023) to Saturday (23/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Septic tanks could struggle to operate effectively from early next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Friday 22/12/2023.

items.description: Upper River Cam in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are continuing to fall after Tuesdays rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are those around the River Cam from Newport to Whittlesford including the Slades. The weather forecast reamains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10 am tomorrow, 22/12/23.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Groundwater levels in East Kent have been rising due to the high amount of rainfall we had in October and November. In response to this groundwater level increase, communities in and around the Elham Valley (Nailbourne), Alkham and Petham may experience impacts from high groundwater. Due to the nature of groundwater levels, other communities across East Kent may also experience increased impact from high groundwater. The Environment Agency is continually monitoring the situation and we are co-ordinating efforts with local authorities and community leaders. Our incident response staff are attending weedscreens and culverts regularly to clear them.

We are issuing this message to allow our communities and partners to act as appropriate.
 
This event may continue for the foreseeable future and until the end of the recharge season, typically in Spring 2024. We will update this message as required, or sooner if the situation changes significantly.
 
To find out more information please visit: www.gov.uk/government/publications/kent-groundwater-situation

items.description: River Wissey in Norfolk
items.message: River levels are continuing to fall after Tuesdays rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land is possible during the next few days. Areas most at risk are those around the River Wissey from Bradenham to Denver including Watton Brook. The weather forecast remains unsettled but mostly dry for several days, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10 am tomorrow, 22/12/23.
